title: 110_hr5954
content: Presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with exposure to toxic agents in the armed forces under laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The new section added to title 38 of the United States Code establishes presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with Project 112, allowing for certain diagnosed diseases to be considered incurred or aggravated by service even without evidence during that period. The new section in title 38 of the United States Code establishes presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with Project 112, allowing certain diagnosed diseases to be considered incurred or aggravated by service without evidence during that period. The Secretary may determine a presumption of service connection for veterans exposed to biological, chemical, or toxic agents during their service in the Armed Forces under Project 112. The new section in title 38 of the United States Code establishes presumptions of service connection for diseases associated with Project 112. Veterans exposed to biological, chemical, or toxic agents during their service may be presumed to have been exposed to such agents unless conclusive evidence proves otherwise. Regulations will provide for a presumption of service connection for diseases covered by the Secretary's determination. The Secretary shall consider sound medical and scientific evidence for determining a positive association between exposure to biological, chemical, or toxic agents during service in the Armed Forces under Project 112 and the occurrence of a diagnosed disease in humans or animals. All available medical and scientific information will be taken into account for these determinations. The Secretary will consider all medical and scientific information available when evaluating reports for determining positive associations between diseases and exposure to toxic agents. The association will be considered positive if credible evidence outweighs evidence against it. If the presumption of service connection for a disease is removed, veterans awarded compensation may be affected. The term 'Project 112' refers to a chemical and biological weapons program conducted by the Department of Defense or other federal entities. Veterans and survivors awarded compensation based on the presumption of a disease before its removal will continue to receive benefits. The text refers to Project 112, a chemical and biological weapons program conducted by the Department of Defense and other federal entities from 1963 to 1973, including Project SHAD. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the relevant chapter. Presumptions of service connection for illnesses associated with service in support of chemical or biological warfare tests or projects. Regulations, personnel records, and report concerning Project 112. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs within 180 days to notify veterans potentially exposed to biological or chemical agents during Project 112. The Secretary of Defense must transmit personnel records within 30 days of enactment, and a report on Project 112 must be submitted to Congress within 1 year. The report on Project 112 to be submitted to Congress will document costs, benefits, and challenges of finding more participants, provide information on all known participants, and address concerns held by the Department of Veterans Affairs, veterans, and veterans service organizations. Project 112 refers to the chemical and biological weapons program conducted by the Department of Defense and other entities from 1963 to 1973.
